intro: Cakile edentula subsp. harperi, commonly known as the Harp's bladderwort, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, cruciform flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in coastal or inland dunes. Its leaves are fleshy and succulent, adapted to store water in arid environments. It produces small, yellowish flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer.
